values.description: MSVC19 is not happy with the use of the experimental namespace. I think that all compilers we use nowadays should support the filesystem namespace directly.
values.title: Remove experimental namespace from std (for VS2019)

summary.raw: MSVC19 is not happy with the use of the experimental namespace. I think that all compilers we use nowadays should support the filesystem namespace directly.
summary.html: MSVC19 is not happy with the use of the experimental namespace. I think that all compilers we use nowadays should support the filesystem namespace directly.

values.description:
In our CI we are using gcc8 compiler for the ign-transport build. I’ve tested in my local system that we can support the default compiler in Bionic \(7.4.x\) with a simple change for the experimental filesystem header. Not sure if there were other reasons to use gcc8.

‌
values.title: Support for defaul GCC Bionic compiler (7.4.x)

summary.raw:
In our CI we are using gcc8 compiler for the ign-transport build. I’ve tested in my local system that we can support the default compiler in Bionic \(7.4.x\) with a simple change for the experimental filesystem header. Not sure if there were other reasons to use gcc8.

‌
summary.html:
In our CI we are using gcc8 compiler for the ign-transport build. I’ve tested in my local system that we can support the default compiler in Bionic (7.4.x) with a simple change for the experimental filesystem header. Not sure if there were other reasons to use gcc8.

‌

values.title: Use prerelease on pipelines for transport8

values.description:
I made a rookie mistake of not properly framing the discovery messages in pull request #403.

This PR adds framing, where a `uint16_t` number that contains the size of the protobuf message is prefixed to each discovery message.

In previous versions of Ignition Transport, the frame header was the size of the message + size of the header. 

I choose a different header number so that we can determine incompatible discovery messages in both Ignition Transport 8+ and Ignition Transport <=7.

Please read the large documentation block in this PR for more information.

# To Test

1. Install both Ignition Transport 7 and Ignition Transport 8.
2. Run the `examples/plublisher` and `examples/subscriber` in both versions of Ignition Transport simultaneously. You should not see cross talk. For example, running the version7 publisher should not cause the version8 subscriber to print "HELLO".
values.title: Ign transport8 discovery fix

summary.raw:
I made a rookie mistake of not properly framing the discovery messages in pull request #403.

This PR adds framing, where a `uint16_t` number that contains the size of the protobuf message is prefixed to each discovery message.

In previous versions of Ignition Transport, the frame header was the size of the message + size of the header. 

I choose a different header number so that we can determine incompatible discovery messages in both Ignition Transport 8+ and Ignition Transport <=7.

Please read the large documentation block in this PR for more information.

# To Test

1. Install both Ignition Transport 7 and Ignition Transport 8.
2. Run the `examples/plublisher` and `examples/subscriber` in both versions of Ignition Transport simultaneously. You should not see cross talk. For example, running the version7 publisher should not cause the version8 subscriber to print "HELLO".
summary.html:
I made a rookie mistake of not properly framing the discovery messages in pull request #403.

This PR adds framing, where a uint16_t number that contains the size of the protobuf message is prefixed to each discovery message.

In previous versions of Ignition Transport, the frame header was the size of the message + size of the header.

I choose a different header number so that we can determine incompatible discovery messages in both Ignition Transport 8+ and Ignition Transport <=7.

Please read the large documentation block in this PR for more information.

To Test

  1. Install both Ignition Transport 7 and Ignition Transport 8.
  2. Run the examples/plublisher and examples/subscriber in both versions of Ignition Transport simultaneously. You should not see cross talk. For example, running the version7 publisher should not cause the version8 subscriber to print "HELLO".

values.description:
This does for ignition-transport7 what pull request #408 does for ignition-transport8. See pull request #408 for information.

**Important Note**

This is not technically needed. Ignition Transport 7 will work fine on the same network as Ignition Transport 8 without this fix. This is just a nice to have, for clarity.

values.title: Update README with command line usage workaround

values.description:
I found that in certain circumstances, ign-transport can lose messages.
I modified the `bench` example to demonstrate the problem.

I believe the underlying problem are message buffers in zeromq. See the fix in NodeShare.cc, and zeromq documentation here](http://api.zeromq.org/4-2:zmq-setsockopt).

## To Test

1. In terminal 1

```
./bench -p -t -f 10
```

2. In terminal 2

```
./bench -r -t -f 10
```

If you comment out the changes in `NodeShared.cc`, then the `bench` test will hang forever because messages are lost.
values.title: [SubT] Flood testing

summary.raw:
I found that in certain circumstances, ign-transport can lose messages.
I modified the `bench` example to demonstrate the problem.

I believe the underlying problem are message buffers in zeromq. See the fix in NodeShare.cc, and zeromq documentation here](http://api.zeromq.org/4-2:zmq-setsockopt).

## To Test

1. In terminal 1

```
./bench -p -t -f 10
```

2. In terminal 2

```
./bench -r -t -f 10
```

If you comment out the changes in `NodeShared.cc`, then the `bench` test will hang forever because messages are lost.
summary.html:
I found that in certain circumstances, ign-transport can lose messages. I modified the bench example to demonstrate the problem.

I believe the underlying problem are message buffers in zeromq. See the fix in NodeShare.cc, and zeromq documentation here](http://api.zeromq.org/4-2:zmq-setsockopt).

To Test

  1. In terminal 1
./bench -p -t -f 10
  1. In terminal 2
./bench -r -t -f 10

If you comment out the changes in NodeShared.cc, then the bench test will hang forever because messages are lost.

* https://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ign-citadel/job/ignition_transport-ci-ign-transport8-homebrew-amd64/4/warnings10Result/

I copied the fix from pr #408.

values.description: The log recorder currently writes to file from an ign-transport callback function. This means that nodes in the same process as the log recorder are blocked from receiving messages from other nodes. When there is heavy disk usage, such as recording a rosbag, the effect of this is noticeable as pointed out by issue https://bitbucket.org/osrf/subt/issues/307.This PR adds a data queue in the recorder and uses a background thread for writing to file.
values.title: Write to disk from a background thread in log recorder

summary.raw: The log recorder currently writes to file from an ign-transport callback function. This means that nodes in the same process as the log recorder are blocked from receiving messages from other nodes. When there is heavy disk usage, such as recording a rosbag, the effect of this is noticeable as pointed out by issue https://bitbucket.org/osrf/subt/issues/307.This PR adds a data queue in the recorder and uses a background thread for writing to file.
summary.html: The log recorder currently writes to file from an ign-transport callback function. This means that nodes in the same process as the log recorder are blocked from receiving messages from other nodes. When there is heavy disk usage, such as recording a rosbag, the effect of this is noticeable as pointed out by issue https://bitbucket.org/osrf/subt/issues/307.This PR adds a data queue in the recorder and uses a background thread for writing to file.

values.description:
It's a bit dangerous to have unlimited be the default buffer size. This sets the default size to 1000, which is the default that zeromq uses as well.

Matching [subt pr](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/subt/pull-requests/401).

values.description: This pull request creates a new connection message to be sent over the discovery channel.
values.title: Move connection handshake to discovery channel - part 1 (Do not review yet)

summary.raw: This pull request creates a new connection message to be sent over the discovery channel.
summary.html: This pull request creates a new connection message to be sent over the discovery channel.

values.description:
The root of the issue is the need to do a ZMQ `connect`, and then, register as a remote subscriber in the publisher’s process. Before this pull request, there was a `sleep` after the ZMQ `connect` to guarantee that the message was always received after the negotiation needed during the `connect` \(see [this line](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/src/35f4c00e998a9cd64262ba5ad989272efa99b4ed/src/NodeShared.cc#lines-970)\). If a network has enough delay, the `100ms` is not enough to complete the `connect` phase. In this case, the ZMQ message registering the subscriber would never reach the publisher. If this node was the only subscriber, the publisher would decide to not send anything over the network.

Solution: As far as I know ZMQ doesn’t offer a way to solve this issue. Instead, we use the UDP multicast channel to send a NewConnection/EndConnection message when a remote subscriber subscribes and unsubscribes respectively.

‌
values.title: Remove some sleeps

summary.raw:
The root of the issue is the need to do a ZMQ `connect`, and then, register as a remote subscriber in the publisher’s process. Before this pull request, there was a `sleep` after the ZMQ `connect` to guarantee that the message was always received after the negotiation needed during the `connect` \(see [this line](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/src/35f4c00e998a9cd64262ba5ad989272efa99b4ed/src/NodeShared.cc#lines-970)\). If a network has enough delay, the `100ms` is not enough to complete the `connect` phase. In this case, the ZMQ message registering the subscriber would never reach the publisher. If this node was the only subscriber, the publisher would decide to not send anything over the network.

Solution: As far as I know ZMQ doesn’t offer a way to solve this issue. Instead, we use the UDP multicast channel to send a NewConnection/EndConnection message when a remote subscriber subscribes and unsubscribes respectively.

‌
summary.html:
The root of the issue is the need to do a ZMQ connect, and then, register as a remote subscriber in the publisher’s process. Before this pull request, there was a sleep after the ZMQ connect to guarantee that the message was always received after the negotiation needed during the connect (see this line). If a network has enough delay, the 100ms is not enough to complete the connect phase. In this case, the ZMQ message registering the subscriber would never reach the publisher. If this node was the only subscriber, the publisher would decide to not send anything over the network.

Solution: As far as I know ZMQ doesn’t offer a way to solve this issue. Instead, we use the UDP multicast channel to send a NewConnection/EndConnection message when a remote subscriber subscribes and unsubscribes respectively.

‌

values.description:
The deprecation was added on version [3.4.0](https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/blob/master/CHANGES.txt#L612).

Our Linux CI is using 3.0.0 and doesn't see the warnings, but homebrew is using 3.11.4.

[Here](https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/blob/master/src/google/protobuf/stubs/common.h#L82)'s an explanation of `GOOGLE_PROTOBUF_VERSION`.
values.title: 👩‍🌾 Protobuf deprecation warnings

values.description:
This is a proposed fix to issue #118.   
I am unsure of how to handle the errors, so the current implementation just reattempts at getting the username until it is successful, but this still does not fix the underlying bug.  
Advise needed.  

‌

values.description:
The `send_flags` command was introduced in zqmcpp in version 4.4.0 . Fixing the problems generated by [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/438/zmq-warnings/diff](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/438/zmq-warnings/diff) .

Tested:

* windows.win32 \(version 4.3.0\)

    ![](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64&build=965)

    [https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition\_transport-ci-pr\_any-windows7-amd64/965/](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/965/))


* windows\_nuc.win10 \(version 4.6.0\)

    ![](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64&build=964)

    [https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition\_transport-ci-pr\_any-windows7-amd64/964/](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/964/)) 



‌
